content: The Act titled "Stop Dangerous Sanctuary Cities Act" ensures cooperation between local and federal law enforcement officers to safeguard communities. The Act "Stop Dangerous Sanctuary Cities Act" mandates cooperation with federal detainer requests under the Immigration and Nationality Act, granting state and local officials authority equivalent to Department of Homeland Security officers. Legal challenges to detentions must be addressed in court. The Act "Stop Dangerous Sanctuary Cities Act" requires state and local officials to comply with federal detainer requests issued by the Department of Homeland Security under the Immigration and Nationality Act. It states that no liability shall lie against the State or political subdivision for actions taken in compliance with the detainer, and officers complying with the detainer are deemed federal employees acting within the scope of their employment. The Act requires state and local officials to comply with federal detainer requests. Section 1346(b) of title 28 provides the exclusive remedy for the plaintiff, with the United States substituted as defendant. No immunity is granted to those who knowingly violate civil or constitutional rights. SEC. 3. SANCTUARY JURISDICTION DEFINED. For the purposes of this Act, a sanctuary jurisdiction is defined as any State or political subdivision that prohibits government entities from sharing information on immigration status or complying with DHS requests. The curr_chunk states that a jurisdiction will not be considered a sanctuary based solely on its policy of not sharing information or complying with DHS requests regarding individuals who come forward as victims or witnesses to a crime. The curr_chunk states that sanctuary jurisdictions will be ineligible for certain federal funds. The curr_chunk amends the Public Works and Economic Development Act of 1965 to make sanctuary jurisdictions ineligible for certain federal grants. The curr_chunk amends the Public Works and Economic Development Act of 1965 to exclude sanctuary jurisdictions from receiving certain federal grants. The Public Works and Economic Development Act of 1965 is amended to prohibit sanctuary jurisdictions from receiving grant funds under this section. The term 'sanctuary jurisdiction' is defined in the Stop Dangerous Sanctuary Cities Act. The Public Works and Economic Development Act of 1965 is amended to prohibit sanctuary jurisdictions from receiving grant funds under this section. The amendment states that grant recipients must not be or become sanctuary jurisdictions during the grant period. No funds can be used for sanctuary jurisdictions, as defined in the Stop Dangerous Sanctuary Cities Act. If a State or unit of general local government is a sanctuary jurisdiction while receiving grant funds under the Public Works and Economic Development Act of 1965, they must return the funds to the Secretary. The returned amounts will be reallocated to non-sanctuary jurisdictions for grants under the same title. If a State or local government is a sanctuary jurisdiction and receives grant funds under the Public Works and Economic Development Act of 1965, the funds must be returned to the Secretary. The returned amounts will then be reallocated to non-sanctuary jurisdictions for grants under the same title. The section specifies that grant funds received by sanctuary jurisdictions under the Public Works and Economic Development Act of 1965 must be returned to the Secretary. These returned funds will then be reallocated to non-sanctuary jurisdictions for grants under the same title, with specific rules for reallocation. This section will take effect on October 1, 2017.
